Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as cdda63820c2e132bc7da119ebcd9ea9a259565cb
I don't know what 'downstream' means here either.

It's a concept in Redfish Cable resources. It represent the physical downstream containers connected to this cable.

For example:
For a Ncsi cable, it has Upstream Chassis which is a motherboard, and a downstream chassis which is the Nic.

Can we define what an "upstream" and "downstream" is?  Do all cables have a directional?

Do we want/need cables to always attach to Chassis?  Do we need a specific association for Chassis like this or should we have one for any Inventory.Item?

upstream points towards the root complex(like motherboard), downstream is the opposite.

Not all cables have direction. If the cables have no direction, we can assume the entity with an alphanumerical-sorted object path which is earlier is considered upstream.

Not all cables are attached to chassis. From Redfish Cable specification, cable could attach to chassis/port/resources. And resources include port and chassis.
```
This property shall contain an array of links to resources that represent the
physical upstream connections connected to this cable. Even if the resource is
already referenced in another property within Links, such as UpstreamPorts or
UpstreamChassis, it shall also be referenced in this property.
```
We could have a specific association for Chassis and Port and have a general association for Resources. 

WDYT?
Another way is to just have a general association for Resources and let the RedfishServer(BMCweb) to figure out the type.
@Patrick, do we want to add the "upstream" and "downstream" definitions in the commit message?
I'm not accepting "upstream" and "downstream" definitions period.

> I'm not accepting "upstream" and "downstream" definitions period.

I'm assuming this naming picked because of Redfish.

This same thing was litigated in DMTF when we did those definitions for cable.  None of the comments here are new arguments, but rehashing of the old.  The TL;DR from what I remember of the discussion in the standard is that:

1. Most cables have a direction.  Upstream and downstream as terms were selected to best match most specifications (USB/PCIe) that use the same terminology in their actual definitions.  "upstream/downstream" in Redfish is all in relation to the root complex, but because not all specifications define it as "root complex", and a cable might be one of the dozens of different types, there's not a great way to document that without using terminology that applies to one cable type and not another.
2. Those cables where the direction doesn't matter, or there's no obvious upstream/downstream (the classic example being identical two servers connected together), it's defined as being arbitrarily assigned, and even though no longer meaningful, picking a second set of properties for "arbitrary directional connection" didn't seem worthwhile to differentiate from directional, especially because it's definitely a corner case that in industry doesn't happen very often.

I agree, this commit needs some more documentation in the description.  What would you propose instead for naming of the directionality of a cable?  I'm not normally one for the "just copy what Redfish did", but this is a case where even though it might appear to not be a great naming, all other options were worse when a bunch of reasonably smart people talked it through.

> Do we want/need cables to always attach to Chassis? Do we need a specific association for Chassis like this or should we have one for any Inventory.Item?

+1. We should be avoiding using type-specific associations in new definitions.  Technically a cable could be attached to damn near anything.

> Another way is to just have a general association for Resources and let the RedfishServer(BMCweb) to figure out the type.

Technically it'd be the mapper that's figuring out the type.  I've started pushing back on a lot of the pattern of "push all the dbus data into bmcweb and then sort through it there".  That's what the mapper is for, if we need better APIs into the mapper, lets build them.

> I'm assuming this naming picked because of Redfish.

Yes, I did pick the name from the Redfish.

> I'm not accepting "upstream" and "downstream" definitions period.

@Patrick, Yes I agree that the "upstream" and "downstream" definitions don't match the association name requirements.

I feel we could have an association between "Cable and Chassis" as 
`connecting and connected_to`.
What do you suggest, it would match the association name requirements as well?

Considering this association name is already used for other items, yes, `connecting` and `connected_to` are acceptable.

You may need a separate interface to identify which is the "upstream" and "downstream" ends of a cable.  This information should not be part of the association itself, as associations do not hold information (and I don't want information encoded as part of the association name).

Maybe we should add this to `Inventory.Item` instead?  Not only can Chassis be connected by cables but Boards can also.  At some level it might be hard to say that anything _can't_ be connected by a cable, so we might as well just do it for Item?

Also, please update Item/Readme.MD with this new connection.
@patrick yes, the association for Item sounds better. Added a new patchset for the same.
None of these association names match the association naming requirements.

Something isn't right here.

1. An item should not be both connected and connecting to a cable.  Pick one.

2. Add reverse connection to Cable.interface.yaml.

Apologies for pushing a new patchset late as I was OOO for some time.
@patrick Yes, my bad repushed with the changes.
